On 10/5/07, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> Derek, I agree that it's interesting to question the mechanism and
> even the justification behind "protecting innovation." Certainly
> such declarations can become dogma if they are repeated enough and
> we should continually scrutinize them to prevent that.
>

I certainly see the justification behind protecting innovation. It's
the particular method of subdividing the population as a way of doing
it that I'm questioning.

> However, I am not completely sure what you are suggesting because
> I'm not sure how you classify an individual as "evolutionarily
> younger?" Isn't every individual evolutionarily descended from the
> first generation and therefore all equivalent in this respect?

An offspring in Generation 10 is younger or newer than a member of
Generation 1. Every new offspring exhibits innovation, unless it's an
exact copy of a network that has appeared previously, correct?

> While I may not understand the proposed remedy, part of your
> argument was philosophical in terms of what speciation really means,
> and I see where you are coming from on that. Yet I do believe that
> what is going on in NEAT is justifiably analogous to natural
> speciation in the way that you question. While you point out that
> everyone in NEAT is competing on the same fitness function and
> therefore it is not really like nature, I would disagree. In
> nature, there is also only one fitness function, which is "to
> reproduce." All species are just variations on ways of getting that
> done. In analogy, all species in NEAT are variations on ways of
> getting done whatever it is the fitness function requires.
> A "niche" in this sense means an alternate means to accomplish a
> task, which is an idea well suited to different topologies and
> weights that do the same thing in different ways.

Just depends on how fine you slice the fitness function. Sure every
individual is trying to perpetuate its genes, but typically a niche
refers to exploiting different resources. A hawk and a fish are both
trying to perpetuate their genes, but they are solving a myriad of
different problems to achieve that goal.

If you had animats in a simulated environment, and you used NEAT to
evolve their behavior, and some learned to forage off artificial
plants, while others evolved to eat other individuals, I'd consider
those clearer niches, but I agree its a fuzzy concept open to
interpretation.

> I also do not fully understand the assertion that "All chromosomes
> in NEAT can potentially mate with one another." NEAT was highly
> influenced by the competing conventions problem, which had been a
> known pathology in neuroevolution for many years. It was perhaps
> the worst of all problems with such sustems. The problem is of
> course exacerbated by differing topologies as well as weights. The
> competing conventions problem is actually a very deep problem
> because there are indeed inviduals that have no hope of mating
> effectively, which is evidenced all over nature. A bird and pig
> will never yield a flying pig, even through some kind of artificial
> insemination or chimeric hybridization. They should simply not be
> mating with each other (since it would waste precious evaluations
> from a computational standpoint, not to mention the ethical
> disaster).
>
> It was well known that enormous damage was being inflicted in non-
> speciated neuroevolving populations wherein similar bird-pig-like
> mating events were happening routinely. Thus, just because one can
> align genes optimally does not mean one should if species have
> diverged too far afield.

Again it just might be a matter of degree. Are networks in different
species in NEAT really as practically different as a pig and a bird?

> In any case, it is probably wise to question the precise mechanisms
> through which NEAT accomplishes or aims to accomplish these ends,
> and I would not be surprised if competitive alternatives arise.
> However, I do still believe that the underlying motivations make
> good sense.

Oh, I think speciation in evolutionary algorithms was a conceptual
innovation. I was just thinking aloud about other possible simpler
ways to accomplish what is ostensibly the main goal of speciation: to
protect innovation.

--Derek
